status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU)  investigated and determined the following:. The City told them that any contractor or inhouse crew working for Comcast have to act professionally at all times while working in the City. They agreed and apologized for what happened and have spoken to the contractors and stated  it will not happen again. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: 2am in the morning and there are utility trucks running... Guys yelling to each other doors banging and a lift in the air at 2AM! People have to sleep. They are working on Comcast lines at 2am. These are not critical lines and work should be done in the day time.

description:
I live on west 7th Street between E and F in South Boston and there are no available parking spots - all open spots have spot savers in them. This is a huge disappointment as I thought folks only had 48 hours to save a spot AND the city of Boston claims that they will come around with a truck to dispose of spot savers once the 48 hours is up. 

Another huge disappointment is the fact that the spaces along west 7th between Dorchester and F Street that are considered school parking from 7am-4pm, are covered in snow. A plow should come by and clear all of those spots that people could be using between the hours of 4:01pm-6:59am. It is currently completely free of cars so it would be extremely easy for a plow to come clean it up. I realize there are many areas and neighborhoods that need help with clean up but this extremely disappointing. If anything, a truck should have already come to take all spot savers so that there are spots to park in for those that don't save spots beyond the 48 hour limit.

I have contact various supervisors at the DPW for the past six months and left over twenty voicemails with NO response back. I find it extremely frustrating. I am a considered resident, mother and pedestrian of Charlestown and would like to find out how to go about having stop signs put in place at three very dangerous intersections in the neighborhood. 
1) intersection of Concord Street and Bartlett (currently only a 1-Way stop and should be a 3-way stop sign as many clueless tourists are walking here including children, pet owners, etc crossing to get to the Monument. The # of cars speeding up Concord St off Bunker Hill is frightening and it is often used as a cut through for vehicles. I have personally had 3 very close encounters. 
2) intersection of High Street and Monument. Need this to be a 3 way stop not just 1. 
3) intersection of Elm St and Bartlett. No stop sign and incredibly dangerous for students walking to Warren Prescott. Currently no stop sign.

status_notes: Case Resolved. park has been plowed and saled on wed jan 31.
description:
I am writing to inform the city that the lack of snow removal at the Eliot Norton Park has become an issue for the parents of students at the Little Panda Early Learning Center.

After the first big storm this year, NOTHING was done at all.  Then again today, absolutely nothing.

Granted, this morning the snow was actively falling, and I fully respect that the city needs to prioritize snow removal based on risk level and the number of resources it has available.

So of course roads and high traffic sidewalk and walkways should be taken care of WHILE the snow falls.

But there is absolutely no excuse for not clearing snow from public parks and walkways after a heavy snowfall.

Especially in an area with an extremely high level of youth activity.  The park is across from the YMCA, and it abuts the Daycare Center that is totally blocked off from entering if there is too much snow.

So I ask, hat in hand, please - please be sure to clear the snow from the walkways at the park going forward

Thanks.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sinkhole as being the responsibility of Eversource Electric. During the normal construction season the permittee would be responsible to repair the bad patch within 2 weeks. However, since we are in the middle of Winter and conditions such as snow storms, temperatures below freezing, and asphalt plants being open only periodically the repair may have to wait longer than the typical 2 weeks. We will require the utility company to patch the settled area asap until a more permanent repair can be scheduled. The CIU has added the location to its data base that tracks unacceptable utility work. The CIU will monitor the progress of the work. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU)  investigated and determined the following:. On Sunday January 21st the contractor was contacted by the homeowner about a broken sewer lateral in the home. Obviously that is emergency work. In this case the contractor started the work on Sunday and came into City Hall  to pull a Public Works  permit on Monday in which we gave him until the 23rd. He told me this morning that it backed up again on Friday which is why he went out there again. The police detail thought it was best to have the street closed. We totally apologize for the inconvenience   But it is important to note that anytime a sewer emergency issue occurs to a homeowner or tenant it is important to get it repaired right away. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. The Boston Transportation does its best to maintain a steady flow of traffic throughout the day and evening. We make adjustments to signal timing when applicable to help improve traffic flow. We also alert the Boston Police and/or the Massachusetts State Police of when there may be an irregular flow of traffic. We are able to view certain areas of the City through a live feed from cameras to our Traffic Management Center; which allows us to make adjustments to the signal timing. We do not however have the authority or the capability to make signal adjustments to traffic signals owned by other authorities. The City of Boston and the Transportation Department apologize for any inconvenience the traffic congestion has caused you. If you have any questions or concerns, or would like to discuss this issue further, please do not hesitate to contact us using the Mayor’s 311 mobile app service.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. All contractors working in the City of Boston are required to have Police details. A Police detail was called for this job. Sometimes, the details are not filled, or a Police officer is up the street,. Unfortunately in this case, the detail was not filled. The PWD has reached out to the Boston Police about the need to fill the detail requests. In this particular case BWSC was patching around its manhole. We are trying to get utility companies to patch around their castings to eliminate the possibility of damage to cars. The good news is the work was done quickly. The City apologizes for the inconvenience for this necessary work. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

Hello, I had a question regarding trash pick up. I live on Tileston Street in the North End which is also directly outside of the small parking lot for the Eliot Upper School. Their trash was picked up at 4am this morning and 5am on Monday morning (Jan 22). Given the close quarters, the noise tends to echo causing a major disruption during the early hours of the morning ( garbage truck left running, dragging/banging barrels etc). Are there any rules or regulations that prevent trash pick up that early? If not, are there rules/regulations around a noise complaint? I don't mean to fuss but it's something I wanted to learn more about as its very disruptive during normal sleeping hours. Thank you in advance and look forward to hearing back from you.
    Thank you!
     Lindsay

status_notes: Case Noted. We continue to evaluate the signal timing along Massachusetts Avenue.  Our focus is to make the intersection safe for those who are most vulnerable in a crash - pedestrians and those on bicycles, while also allowing for more efficient traffic flow.
description: Why is there so much traffic at a standstill for on mass Avenue

Speeding traffic all day long. Unfortunately I have been confined st home with a knee replacement. On my security cameras I see cars all day long speeding up and down the street. DEsoto rd is the street that school kids walk between the Beethoven and Ohrenberger school since they became combined. We need speed limit signs and Go slow school zone signs. I believe most of the speeders are parents driving between schools dropping off and picking up their children. A police officer on the street with a radar or the flashing portable speed trailer would greatly help

status_notes: Case Resolved. Thanks for your recommendation regarding honking. While we currently do not have any regulations that allow us to fine for honking this is something we will look at in the future.
description: So I saw in NYC that they have street signs indicating that you will be fined for honking, I believe it would be extremely beneficial to throw some of those up because the amount of times I've been kept awake due to the excessive honking (at ALL hours of the day. And when I say all I mean ALL hours) is getting out of hand. We all have road rage deep down inside us, but this intersection proves that some people are just savages. It would be immensely appreciated!
